etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Anna Seward (1742–1809), poet and correspondent. Originally from im- + personize + -ation, probably as an alteration of impersonation

definitions: The action of representing or imagining an immaterial thing or abstract quality as a person or being; personification. Also (and in earliest use): an example of this; a personification or embodiment of a quality, idea, etc.
The action or an act of pretending to be someone else, usually for the purpose of entertainment or fraud; imitation of a person's voice, mannerisms, etc.
